coach.title: AI Care Coach

resources.title: Resources
resources.subtitle: Guides, articles, and local support to help you on your caregiving journey

coach.intro: Ask me anything about caring for {{name}}. I know their routine, preferences, and general best practices.
coach.disclaimer: I'm here to support you, not replace medical advice. For health concerns, always consult your doctor.
coach.disclaimerShort: Care Coach provides general guidance only. Always consult healthcare professionals for medical advice.
coach.greetingIntro: I'm here to help you care for {{patientName}}. Ask me anything about daily care, activities, or managing challenging situations.
coach.taskAddedError: Failed to add task. Please try again.
coach.noteAddedError: Failed to save note. Please try again.

suggestions.stayEngaged: How can I help {{name}} stay engaged during the day?
suggestions.agitated: {{name}} seems agitated in the evenings. What can I do?
suggestions.rainyDays: What activities work for rainy days?
suggestions.siblings: Help me talk to my siblings about sharing care
suggestions.repetitive: How do I handle repetitive questions?

insight.title: For You
insight.fallback: Check in on {{name}}'s day to get personalized insights

planPrepare.title: Plan & Prepare
planPrepare.subtitle: Guided workflows
planPrepare.review_week_desc: What went well, what needs attention

askAnything.title: Ask Anything
askAnything.placeholder: What's on your mind about caring for {{name}}?

situationPrompts.refusing_food: {{name}} is refusing to eat right now. What should I do?
situationPrompts.refusing_medication: {{name}} won't take their medication. I need help right now.
situationPrompts.agitated: {{name}} is very agitated right now. How do I help calm things down?
situationPrompts.not_recognizing: {{name}} doesn't recognize me right now. It's really hard. What do I do?
situationPrompts.repetitive_questions: {{name}} keeps asking the same question over and over. How do I handle this patiently?
situationPrompts.sundowning: It's evening and {{name}} is getting really restless and confused. Help me with sundowning.
situationPrompts.wants_to_leave: {{name}} wants to leave the house and is insisting on going somewhere. What do I do?
situationPrompts.caregiver_overwhelmed: I'm feeling overwhelmed and losing patience right now. I need support.

workflowPrompts.plan_tomorrow: Let's plan a good day for {{name}} tomorrow. What do you suggest based on what's been working?
workflowPrompts.doctor_visit: I have a doctor visit coming up for {{name}}. Can you help me prepare a summary of how things have been going?
workflowPrompts.review_week: Let's review how this week went for {{name}}. What patterns do you see?
workflowPrompts.adjust_plan: I'd like to review {{name}}'s care plan and see what we should change based on how things are going.

coach.insightDiscussPrompt: I saw this insight: "{{insight}}". Can you tell me more about what this means and what I should do?

family.caregiverLimitReached: You've reached the free tier limit for family members. Upgrade to add more.

toolkit.pageSubtitle: Practical tools and support for your wellbeing
toolkit.introMessage: Hi {{name}}! This is your space for quick relief, support, and self-care.

box-breathing.name: Box Breathing
box-breathing.step0: Get comfortable and close your eyes
box-breathing.step1: Breathe in slowly through your nose
box-breathing.step3: Breathe out slowly through your mouth
box-breathing.step5: Breathe in slowly through your nose
box-breathing.step7: Breathe out slowly through your mouth
box-breathing.step9: Breathe in slowly through your nose
box-breathing.step11: Breathe out slowly through your mouth
box-breathing.step13: Breathe in slowly through your nose
box-breathing.step15: Breathe out slowly through your mouth
box-breathing.step17: Breathe in slowly through your nose
box-breathing.step19: Breathe out slowly through your mouth
box-breathing.step21: Breathe in slowly through your nose
box-breathing.step23: Breathe out slowly through your mouth
box-breathing.step24: Well done. Take a moment to notice how you feel.

54321-grounding.name: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
54321-grounding.step0: Take a slow, deep breath and look around you
54321-grounding.step1: Name 5 things you can SEE right now
54321-grounding.step2: Name 4 things you can TOUCH right now
54321-grounding.step3: Name 3 things you can HEAR right now
54321-grounding.step4: Name 2 things you can SMELL right now
54321-grounding.step5: Name 1 thing you can TASTE right now
54321-grounding.step6: Take another deep breath. You are here, and you are safe.

gratitude-moment.name: Gratitude Moment
gratitude-moment.step0: Close your eyes and take a calming breath
gratitude-moment.step1: Think of one person you are grateful for and why
gratitude-moment.step2: Think of one thing that happened today that was good, even if small
gratitude-moment.step3: Think of one thing about yourself that you appreciate
gratitude-moment.step4: Hold those three things in your mind and breathe deeply
gratitude-moment.step5: Carry this feeling of gratitude with you.

progressive-muscle-relaxation.name: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step0: Sit or lie down comfortably. Close your eyes.
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step1: Squeeze both fists tightly for 5 seconds...
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step2: Release and feel the tension melt away
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step3: Tense your shoulders — lift them toward your ears...
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step4: Release and let your shoulders drop
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step5: Scrunch your face tightly — forehead, eyes, jaw...
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step6: Release and let your face relax completely
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step8: Release and breathe into your belly
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step9: Squeeze your legs and feet tightly...
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step10: Release and feel the warmth flow through your legs
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step11: Breathe deeply. Your whole body is relaxed.
progressive-muscle-relaxation.step12: Gently open your eyes when you are ready.

mindful-break.name: Mindful Break
mindful-break.step0: Pause whatever you are doing. This moment is yours.
mindful-break.step1: Close your eyes and take 3 slow, deep breaths
mindful-break.step2: Notice how your body feels right now — no need to change anything
mindful-break.step3: Listen to the sounds around you, near and far
mindful-break.step4: Feel the surface beneath you and the air on your skin
mindful-break.step5: Silently say: "I am doing my best, and that is enough."
mindful-break.step7: Gently open your eyes. You are refreshed.

breathing-478.name: 4-7-8 Breathing
breathing-478.step0: Sit comfortably and relax your shoulders
breathing-478.step1: Breathe in quietly through your nose for 4 counts
breathing-478.step3: Exhale completely through your mouth for 8 counts
breathing-478.step4: Breathe in quietly through your nose for 4 counts
breathing-478.step6: Exhale completely through your mouth for 8 counts
breathing-478.step7: Breathe in quietly through your nose for 4 counts
breathing-478.step9: Exhale completely through your mouth for 8 counts
breathing-478.step10: Breathe in quietly through your nose for 4 counts
breathing-478.step12: Exhale completely through your mouth for 8 counts
breathing-478.step13: Breathe in quietly through your nose for 4 counts
breathing-478.step15: Exhale completely through your mouth for 8 counts
breathing-478.step16: Notice how much calmer your body feels now.

permission-slip.name: Permission Slip
permission-slip.step0: Take a deep breath and give yourself a moment
permission-slip.step1: Say to yourself: "I give myself permission to not be perfect today"
permission-slip.step2: Say: "I give myself permission to ask for help"
permission-slip.step3: Say: "I give myself permission to feel what I feel without guilt"
permission-slip.step4: Say: "I give myself permission to take a break"
permission-slip.step5: Say: "I am doing my best, and that is enough"
permission-slip.step6: Take a deep breath and hold these words close
permission-slip.step7: You deserve compassion too. Carry this with you.

quick-walk.name: Quick Walk Prompt
quick-walk.step0: Stand up and stretch your arms above your head
quick-walk.step1: Walk to the nearest window or door and look outside
quick-walk.step2: Take 5 slow steps and feel each foot touch the ground
quick-walk.step3: Look up — notice the sky, ceiling, or something above you
quick-walk.step5: Shake your hands and arms loosely for a few seconds
quick-walk.step7: You moved your body. That counts. Well done.

help.title: Ask for Help
help.limitReached: You can send up to 5 help requests per day.
help.message_need_break: I could really use a break. Could someone take over for a bit?
help.message_handle_meds: Can someone help with medication today?
help.message_need_visit: It would mean a lot if someone could visit today.
help.message_groceries: Could someone help pick up groceries?

agent.title: Wellbeing Companion
agent.disclaimer: For emotional support only. Not medical advice.
agent.rateLimited: Take a breather — you can chat again shortly.
agent.errorMessage: Could not connect. Please try again.

prompts.calmDown: Help me calm down in 2 minutes
prompts.needEnergy: I need energy but can't take a break
prompts.poorSleep: I couldn't sleep well last night
prompts.needMoment: I need a moment just for myself

burnout.title: We notice you may need extra support
burnout.message: Your recent check-ins show elevated stress or low energy. That is completely understandable — caregiving is hard.

support.title: Need Support?
support.description: Caregiving is challenging. It is okay to ask for help.

toolkit.footer: Remember: You can't pour from an empty cup. Your wellbeing matters too.

weeklyStats.title: Weekly Insights
weeklyStats.subtitle: Your 7-day wellbeing summary
weeklyStats.noData: Complete daily check-ins to see your weekly trends.

crisis.title: Crisis Hub
crisis.subtitle: Real-time crisis management and de-escalation support

actions.alertFamilyDesc: Send push notification to all caregivers
actions.alertFamilyFailed: Failed to notify family. Please try again.
actions.crisisAlertBody: {{caregiverName}} needs help with {{patientName}}. Please check in.
actions.contactPrimaryDesc: Reach the primary caregiver via email
actions.logEventDesc: Record this moment in the crisis journal

wizard.breathingTitle: Let's start with a calming breath
wizard.breathingInstruction: Breathe in slowly... hold... breathe out...
wizard.completionTitle: Well done. You handled that with care.
wizard.completionDesc: Would you like to record any notes about what happened?
wizard.crisisNotesPlaceholder: What happened? What helped? Any triggers noticed...

history.title: Recent Crisis Events
history.noEvents: No crisis events in the last 30 days.

stayCalm.title: Stay Calm
stayCalm.detail: Take a slow, deep breath. Your calm energy will help them feel safe.
stayCalm.script: I'm right here with you. Everything is okay.

validateFeelings.title: Validate Feelings
validateFeelings.detail: Say 'I can see you're upset. That must be really hard.' Don't argue or correct.
validateFeelings.script: I can see you're upset. That must be really difficult.

simplifyEnvironment.title: Simplify the Environment
simplifyEnvironment.detail: Use short, simple sentences. One idea at a time. Avoid asking 'why' questions.
simplifyEnvironment.script: Let's make things simpler. One thing at a time.

redirectAttention.title: Redirect Attention
redirectAttention.detail: Gently change the subject. Suggest a familiar activity, song, or walk.
redirectAttention.script: How about we try something different? Let's take a little walk together.

useGentleTouch.title: Use Gentle Touch
useGentleTouch.detail: If welcome, a gentle hand on the arm can be reassuring. Watch their response.
useGentleTouch.script: Is it okay if I hold your hand? I'm right here.

giveSpace.title: Give Space
giveSpace.detail: If nothing works, ensure safety and give them space. It's okay to step back.
giveSpace.script: I'll be right nearby if you need me. Take your time.

crisis.noHelplineAvailable: No helpline found for your country

scenarios.title: What's happening?
scenarios.subtitle: Tap a situation for step-by-step guidance

patterns.title: Pattern Insight
patterns.noEvents: Log incidents to see patterns over time.
patterns.fewEvents: {{count}} incidents logged. More data needed for patterns.

personalization.label: What calms {{name}}
personalization.empty: Add calming strategies in {{name}}'s biography to see personalized tips here.

steps.title: You first
steps.instruction: Take one slow breath before you do anything. You can't calm someone if you're not calm.

steps.title: Quick check — could something physical be wrong?
steps.instruction: Pain, hunger, needing the bathroom, or an infection can all cause agitation.

steps.title: Lower the temperature
steps.instruction: Speak slowly and softly. Don't argue, correct, or explain. Validate what they're feeling.
tips: "I can see you're upset. I'm here."
Reduce noise — turn off TV, close windows
Give them physical space, don't crowd

steps.title: Redirect, don't reason
steps.instruction: Gently change the subject or environment. Don't try to logic them out of it.
tips: Suggest a walk or move to another room
Offer a snack or warm drink

steps.title: When to get help
steps.instruction: If agitation lasts more than 30 minutes, if they're at risk of hurting themselves or you, or if this is a sudden new behavior — call emergency services.

steps.title: Check the usual places first
steps.instruction: Most people with dementia go to familiar places — a former workplace, a childhood home, a neighbor's house.
tips: Check the garden, garage, nearby streets
Ask neighbors if they've seen them
Check places they used to go regularly

steps.title: Use their location
steps.instruction: If location tracking is set up, check their current position now.

steps.title: Alert the family
steps.instruction: Let everyone know immediately. More eyes searching is better.

steps.title: Call police if not found within 15 minutes
steps.instruction: Don't wait. People with dementia are at high risk of injury. Call emergency services and tell them the person has dementia.

steps.title: Pause — this isn't defiance
steps.instruction: Refusal is almost always fear, confusion, or discomfort. They may not understand what you're asking.

steps.title: Step back and try differently
steps.instruction: Don't push. Come back in 15–20 minutes and approach as if it's the first time.
tips: Break the task into smaller steps

steps.title: Make it feel safe
steps.instruction: Explain each step before you do it. Move slowly. Keep them warm.
tips: Play their favorite music during the task

steps.title: Is this a pattern?
steps.instruction: If they consistently refuse the same task, log it. There may be an underlying issue — pain, fear, sensitivity. Discuss with their doctor.

steps.title: Don't argue — it's real to them
steps.instruction: Acknowledge what they're experiencing without confirming it's true.
tips: "That sounds frightening. I'm here with you."

steps.title: Check the environment
steps.instruction: Shadows, reflections, TV sounds, and clutter can trigger misinterpretation.
checklist: TV or radio on in background?

steps.title: Redirect gently
steps.instruction: Shift their attention to something concrete and comforting.
tips: Go for a short walk together
Make a cup of tea together

steps.title: When to call the doctor
steps.instruction: If hallucinations are new, frequent, or causing extreme distress. Sudden onset can indicate infection, medication side effects, or delirium.

steps.title: Recognize the pattern
steps.instruction: Sundowning typically starts late afternoon. This is extremely common and not something they can control.

steps.title: Adjust the environment now
steps.instruction: Reduce all stimulation and create safety signals.
tips: Turn on warm lights before it gets dark
Turn off or lower the TV volume
Reduce the number of people in the room

steps.title: Offer calming activities
steps.instruction: Gentle, repetitive, familiar activities work best.
tips: Looking through a photo album together

steps.title: Prevent it tomorrow
steps.instruction: Log the episode with timing details. Patterns help adjust schedules — more morning activity, less afternoon caffeine.

steps.title: Don't move them
steps.instruction: Unless they're in immediate danger, don't try to lift or move them.

steps.title: Can they get up?
steps.instruction: If no obvious injury, help them up slowly in stages.

steps.title: Call for help if...
steps.instruction: Head injury, can't get up, severe pain, confusion worse than usual, or bleeding that won't stop.

steps.title: After the fall
steps.instruction: Log this event and mention it to their doctor. Repeated falls can indicate medication issues or disease progression.

steps.title: Breathe — this is the disease, not them
steps.instruction: They genuinely don't remember asking. Your frustration is valid, but showing it makes them more anxious.

steps.title: What are they really asking?
steps.instruction: The surface question is rarely the real question. "What time is dinner?" might mean "I'm hungry."
checklist: Could they be hungry, thirsty, or bored?
Is there an upcoming event causing worry?

steps.title: Respond to the feeling
steps.instruction: Answer the emotion behind the question rather than the literal words.
tips: Write the answer on a visible whiteboard
Provide a simple, reassuring answer each time
Redirect to a hands-on activity after answering
Use visual schedules to reduce uncertainty

steps.title: Protect your own wellbeing
steps.instruction: Tag out with another caregiver if possible. Use headphones with gentle music when you need a mental break.

steps.title: Your safety comes first
steps.instruction: If you feel physically unsafe, step back immediately. Do not try to restrain them.
tips: Keep your voice low and calm

steps.title: Ground yourself
steps.instruction: Aggression triggers fight-or-flight in you too. Take one moment to breathe.

steps.title: What triggered this?
steps.instruction: Aggression is almost always a reaction — pain, fear, frustration, sensory overload.
checklist: Were they being asked to do something?
Was the environment noisy or chaotic?

steps.title: Give space and time
steps.instruction: Back off. Stop the triggering activity. Come back in 15–20 minutes as if nothing happened.

steps.title: When this is an emergency
steps.instruction: If they have a weapon, if someone is injured, or if the aggression doesn't subside — call emergency services.

steps.title: Keep the environment safe
steps.instruction: If they're awake and moving around at night, your first priority is safety.
tips: Lock exterior doors if wandering is a concern

steps.title: What woke them?
steps.instruction: Night waking can be caused by pain, needing the bathroom, medication timing, or hunger.
checklist: Did a noise or light wake them?

steps.title: Guide them back gently
steps.instruction: Don't argue about what time it is. Redirect them back to bed with calming cues.
tips: Sit with them until they settle

steps.title: Improve tomorrow night
steps.instruction: More daytime activity, no caffeine after noon, consistent bedtime routine, limit naps to 30 minutes.

steps.title: Acknowledge your frustration
steps.instruction: Being followed everywhere is exhausting. Those feelings are valid. Take a breath.

steps.title: Why are they following you?
steps.instruction: Shadowing is driven by anxiety and fear of abandonment. Being near you is their only source of safety.
checklist: Has there been a recent routine change?
Are they in an unfamiliar environment?

steps.title: Reduce their anxiety
steps.instruction: Help them feel secure without being physically present every moment.
tips: Give them a "job" near where you are
Leave a personal item with them as a comfort anchor
"I'm just in the kitchen, I'll be right back"
Try familiar TV or music as a companion

steps.title: Build in breaks for yourself
steps.instruction: Ask someone to sit with them while you take 20 minutes. Even 10 minutes alone helps.
tips: It's okay to gently close the bathroom door
This behavior often reduces with a stable routine
